The idea that cultures are so very distinct is a recent invention in America. The most overwhelmingly significant distinction of ‘culture’ is language. The second is law. The third is religion. People marry. Have children. Bury their parents. These things are all the same worldwide, but they are done in different languages, according to different regulations with different religious rites attending. But is it really that different? The term African-American, in fact, was coined among academics precisely because that ‘race’ of people could not be squeezed into ‘black history’. These people did not call themselves ‘black’ before the 1960s. Before then, they were Negroes. Before then, they were Coloreds. So in fact, you could call these three separate cultures covering just 5 generations. So yes you can definitely say the use of language, the context of law and the rites of religions have changed over the past 120 years, but are they really that different? As to the matter of ‘real’ culture, well I don’t thing most Americans study enough to make an educated distinction, but there are millions of distinctions and people decide to draw attention to them all the time. So if you can say that Rock & Roll (People singing in English with guitars and drums in 4/4/ time about love) is different than Country (People singing in English with guitars and drums in 4/4 time about love), then yes every identifiable set is a real culture. So they’re all distinct and real, but are they really that different? Keeping in mind that Pan-Africanism was a failed experiment to establish cultural and political exchanges between African blacks and American blacks, there isn’t much left to be said about a shared culture. But there is no great need for that, nor any great call for it. Those few Americans who go to live in Africa and those few Africans who come to live in America aren’t making large impacts on either continent.

Lots to deal with here, so I'm going to handle it one bite at a time. “How African is African-American culture?” The biggest problem with this question is that Africa doesn't have a single culture, coastal West Africa alone is home to over 250 languages, religions, histories, customs and traditions. Over 250 cultures. On a fraction of a coastline. And African Americans are not really different in this regard. African Americans in New York, DC, and Florida have great cultural differences. But how like the various African peoples are we? Well for starters we still have the vestiges of a tonal language. African American Vernacular English is largely somatic and tonal. Our means of religious expression is a carry over from our ancestors. Our reverence for our mothers. Many of our social taboos. “ One view is that we have basically lost all traces of ancestral African culture except in a few cases.” For anyone to be able to say that they'd need to have some knowledge of African cultures. By show of hands, who can tell me the relationship between the Eυe, the Asante, and the Akeyem is so important to African Americans? Anyone who cannot answer that question can even enter into this conversation with you. “ Some also believe that we as black Americans have no real culture of our own. Why is this?” Because you cannot look for salvation within if the savior is outside.

The Blues is culture, that spawned the most dominant, diverse, and global culture the world has ever seen Rock’N’Roll. Before I talk about the ridiculousness of the term “African Culture”, let me first say that all societies on this planet have a culture. Everyone. Why is that? Culture is simply the way of life of a people. Now think about this for a second. What group of people has no way of life? Even corporate entities have a culture. This brings us back to the latter part of the question. Of course, black Americans do have a culture, vibrant and widely popular one at that. As to how African that culture is, well, um… it's not. African-American culture is essentially American pop culture. It was created by Americans from an American perspective. The only thing African about it is that it was created by a group of people who share the same skin colour as black Africans. That's it. Now let's come back to the term “African Culture”. What exactly is it? Africans do not think about their culture as a single monolith. Our cultural identities are based on our ethnicities and not on the entire continent itself. Even people in the same country don't think of themselves as coming from the same culture if they belong to different ethnicities. Well, some countries like mine (Ghana) may have a collective Ghanaian identity, however, at heart, we still acknowledge our different ways of life according to our ethnicities. If I were African-American (a term which has always baffled me by the way), I will not worry about how African my culture is. You already have one — a rather cool one at that. As to which one is better, muhhahahaha, maybe another time.

To add to all the other answers, I’d like to draw attention to the Gullah people in the South Carolina (and formerly Georgia) Lowcountry and Sea Islands. The Gullah people have been able to preserve much of their African cultural heritage because of climate, geography, cultural pride, and patterns of importation of enslaved Africans. Enslaved persons from the Central Western region of Africa, originating primarily from the Mende populations of what is today Sierra Leone, and transported to some areas of Brazil (including Bahia), the enslaved Gullah-Gheechee people were traded in what was then Charlestowne, South Carolina. According to British historian P.E.H. Hair, Gullah culture developed as a creole culture in the colonies and United States from the peoples of many different African cultures who came together there. These included the Baga, Fula, Kissi, Kpelle, Limba, Mandinka, Mende, Susu, Temne, Vai, and Wolof of the Rice Coast, and many from Angola, Igbo, Calabar, West Congo, and the Gold Coast. By the middle of the 18th century, thousands of acres in the Georgia and South Carolina Lowcountry, and the Sea Islands were developed as African rice fields. African farmers from the "Rice Coast" brought the skills for cultivation and tidal irrigation that made rice farming one of the most successful industries in early America. The subtropical climate encouraged the spread of malaria and yellow fever, which were both carried and transmitted by mosquitoes. These tropical diseases were endemic in Africa and had been carried by enslaved Africans to the colonies. [20] Mosquitoes in the swamps and inundated rice fields of the Lowcountry picked up and spread the diseases to English and European settlers, as well. Malaria and yellow fever soon became endemic in the region. Because they had acquired some immunity in their homeland, Africans were more resistant to these tropical fevers than were the Europeans. As the rice industry was developed, planters continued to import enslaved Africans. By about 1708, South Carolina had a black majority. [21] Coastal Georgia developed a black majority after rice cultivation expanded there in the mid-18th century. Malaria and yellow fever became endemic. Fearing these diseases, many white planters and their families left the Lowcountry during the rainy spring and summer months when fevers ran rampant. [19] Others lived mostly in cities such as Charleston rather than on the isolated plantations, especially those on the Sea Islands. The planters left their European or African "rice drivers", or overseers, in charge of the rice plantations. [19] These had hundreds of laborers, with African traditions reinforced by new imports from the same regions. Over time, the Gullah people developed a creole culture in which elements of African languages, cultures, and community life were preserved to a high degree. Their culture developed in a distinct way, different from that of the enslaved African Americans in states such as North Carolina, Virginia, and Maryland where the enslaved lived in smaller groups, and had more sustained and frequent interactions with whites and British American culture. [22] Source; Gullah - Wikipedia

Africa has many a culture. More than 500 languages. More than 50 religions. 53 countries… etc. Most mainstream African Americans are closer to West Africans than the other Africans. In Uganda, a part of East Africa, where I stay, we have two main ethinicities; the Bantu who speak more than 20 languages and about 100 dailects in Uganda alone, and the Luo who also speak multiple languages and dailects. Although the cultures within the Bantu are very similar, there is a big difference between the cultures between the Luo and the Bantu. The more modern African culture, common among the youth and Urban areas, is majorly influenced by Hollywood and pop music, especially hip-hop and Jamaica's Dance Hall music. So I'd say African-American culture is more American than it is African but that's mostly because it's extremely hard to put a simplistic definition on what African culture is or should be in a general. On whether you have lost all traces of ancestral culture, I'd say that after colonization most of Africa decided to part with many a trace of ancestral African culture in favor of European, especially British culture. You're not alone.

My 4 year old does not understand the Jamaican dialect. His father being from a different country doesn’t speak it so the dialect isn’t spoken at home. My son’s favorite food is pasta and meat sauce. If my children don’t have a Jamaican culture then it’s fair to say people who probably can’t identify a known relative from Africa might have lost all the culture except for tiny bits. A culture is mostly based on where you live now with some tiny bits of history passed down to you by ancestors. I know a man who has Irish ancestry and every year at st Patrick’s day he makes corned beef and cabbage. He does it because he knows of his ancestry and knows the food they eat. He has never ever seen his parents make that food. I myself is part Irish, small compared to my African heritage. I suspect most African Americans are influenced by their current geographical location instead of culture from their very far past.

Dr Diop in the ‘African origins of civilisation’ categorised African culture as distinct from European culture… Presuming that his theory has some validity, Africans in the diaspora having become shaped by a non African culture over the past 400 years, are somewhat closer to Europeans than the indigenous African. Despite the fact that indigenous Africans were also influenced by Europeans via colonialism. See- colonial map of Africa  Religion, economic systems, and political systems have changed in Africa via the colonialism processes. Most Africans today are either Christian or Muslim. It can be argued that individual values and beliefs shape motivations and behaviour. Some have debated whether religion is the deification of culture. See-https://www.africanamerica.org/topic/religion-the-deification-of-culture?nc=1 Nevertheless, there is a uniqueness about how Africans express and manifest European culture. Matriarchal traditions and religious idealism remain strong cultural expressions among Africans, whether on the continent or the diaspora. However, there has been enduring conflicts between the values of individualism and collectivism among Africans, with more assimilated Africans tending more towards individualism than those who retain authentic African culture.
